top_categories.workout_context: Bootlegger 100’s north georgia mountains gravel (80%), dirt roads (20%) demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Bootlegger 100 rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Racing Bootlegger 100 isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Bootlegger 100 when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
At 100 miles, Bootlegger 100 punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Bootlegger 100’s 10,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Bootlegger 100. Make this intensity feel like home.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Bootlegger 100 — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Bootlegger 100’s north georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical descents and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for Bootlegger 100’s 10,000ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Bootlegger 100 — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on north georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical descents.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Bootlegger 100’s north georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical descents delivers on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Bootlegger 100’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Bootlegger 100 demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride north georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical descents at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: north georgia mountains gravel (80%), dirt roads (20%), steep appalachian climbs. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 100 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, TT Threshold, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 100 miles of north georgia mountains—steep climbs, technical descents in Dahlonega, Georgia (North Georgia mountains).
